GenAiLog.html.title: ✅ 1. Install DocFX | BooseApp
GenAiLog.html.summary: me: Hi have a .net c# project i want to make a docsite for using docfx whats the commands i need for this any any changes to files ChatGPT: Below is a clear, minimal set of steps and commands to create a DocFX documentation site for a .NET C# project, including what files you need to add or modify. ✅ 1. Install DocFX If you don’t already have DocFX installed: Option 1 — .NET tool (recommended for DocFX 2.70+) dotnet tool update -g docfx Option 2 — Chocolatey choco install docfx -y ✅ 2. Create a DocFX project Navigate to your solution root: cd YourSolution/ docfx init -q This creates a docfx_project folder containing: docfx.json — main configuration file api/ — API documentation placeholder articles/ — pages for guides and tutorials index.md — homepage ✅ 3. Generate API Documentation from Your C# Code Inside docfx.json, make sure the metadata section points to your project or solution: Example for a solution: "metadata": [ { "src": [ { "files": [ "**/*.csproj" ], "cwd": "../" } ], "dest": "api" } ] Example for a single project: "metadata": [ { "src": [ { "files": [ "YourProject.csproj" ] } ], "dest": "api" } ] ✅ 4. Add XML documentation output to your C# project DocFX reads the XML comments from your code. Edit your .csproj to include: <PropertyGroup> <GenerateDocumentationFile>true</GenerateDocumentationFile> <NoWarn>1591</NoWarn> </PropertyGroup> ✅ 5. Build metadata (API docs) From inside the docfx project folder: docfx metadata DocFX will scan your C# code and generate YAML files under /api. ✅ 6. Build the full documentation site docfx build This generates your static site under _site. ✅ 7. Preview the documentation locally docfx serve _site Open: http://localhost:8080 📁 Summary of File Changes File What to change YourProject.csproj Add XML doc generation block docfx.json Update metadata → src to point to .csproj or .sln articles/*.md Write your guides/tutorials index.md Edit your docsite homepage ⭐ Typical Folder Structure After Setup YourSolution/ ├─ src/ │ └─ YourProject.csproj ├─ docfx_project/ │ ├─ api/ │ ├─ articles/ │ ├─ index.md │ ├─ docfx.json │ └─ _site/ (generated) If you want, I can also generate a ready-to-use docfx.json for your exact project structure—just tell me what your folders are called. me: PS C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL> docfx metadata FileNotFoundException: Cannot find config file C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL\docfx.json at (DocfxConfig , string configDirectory) GetConfig(string configFile) in Docset.cs:73 at void b__0() in MetadataCommand.cs:16 at int Run(LogOptions options, Action run) in CommandHelper.cs:48 at int Execute(CommandContext context, MetadataCommandOptions options) in MetadataCommand.cs:14 at Task Execute(CommandContext context, CommandSettings settings) in CommandOfT.cs:40 at async Task Execute(CommandTree leaf, CommandTree tree, CommandContext context, ITypeResolver resolver, IConfiguration configuration) in CommandExecutor.cs:259 ChatGPT: Ah! That error is actually very clear: FileNotFoundException: Cannot find config file ... docfx.json It means DocFX is looking for a docfx.json file in your current folder, but it doesn’t exist. The metadata command requires a config file to know what projects to scan and where to put the output. How to fix Option 1 — Initialize a new DocFX project From your solution root: docfx init -q This will create a docfx_project folder with a docfx.json file. After that, either: cd docfx_project docfx metadata or reference the config file explicitly: docfx metadata docfx.json Option 2 — Create a docfx.json manually If you don’t want the default init structure, create a docfx.json in your project root: { "metadata": [ { "src": [ { "files": ["*.csproj"] } ], "dest": "api" } ], "build": { "content": [ { "files": ["articles/**.md"] }, { "files": ["api/**.yml"] }, { "files": ["index.md"] } ], "dest": "_site" } } Then you can run: docfx metadata docfx build ✅ Tip If your path has spaces (like OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University), wrap paths in quotes when running commands. DocFX usually handles this, but it avoids headaches. If you want, I can write a ready-to-use docfx.json specifically for your ase-boose-assignment-BradRL project that points to your .csproj and sets up articles and api automatically. This will get you running in one go. Do you want me to do that? me: code to add to it for this to work ? ChatGPT: Perfect! Since your .csproj is already there, the only thing you need to do to make DocFX generate API docs from your project is enable XML documentation output. DocFX reads the XML comments from your build to generate the metadata. Here’s exactly what to add to your .csproj: Add inside the existing <PropertyGroup> <GenerateDocumentationFile>true</GenerateDocumentationFile> <NoWarn>1591</NoWarn> <GenerateDocumentationFile> → Tells the compiler to produce an XML file with all your code comments. <NoWarn>1591</NoWarn> → Suppresses warnings for missing XML comments (optional but convenient). So your <PropertyGroup> will look like this: <PropertyGroup> <OutputType>WinExe</OutputType> <TargetFramework>net8.0-windows</TargetFramework> <Nullable>enable</Nullable> <UseWindowsForms>true</UseWindowsForms> <ImplicitUsings>enable</ImplicitUsings> <GenerateDocumentationFile>true</GenerateDocumentationFile> <NoWarn>1591</NoWarn> </PropertyGroup> After that Rebuild your project so the XML file is created: dotnet build You should see a .xml file next to your .exe or .dll in bin/Debug/net8.0-windows. Then generate DocFX metadata: docfx metadata Build the site: docfx build docfx serve _site You’ll now have a full documentation site with your API reference included. If you want, I can write the exact docfx.json that points to your .csproj and sets up articles, API, and homepage ready to go for your project folder. It would save you a few manual steps. me: docfx metadata No files are found with glob pattern **/*.csproj, excluding , under directory "C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL\C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL\BradleyLeach_BooseApp" warning: No .NET API project detected. Creating output... warning: No .NET API detected for . Build succeeded with warning. 2 warning(s) 0 error(s) ChatGPT: Ah! Now the issue is clear — the error message is showing that DocFX cannot find your .csproj file because the path in your docfx.json is wrong. Notice this part of your error: under directory "C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL\C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL\BradleyLeach_BooseApp" It’s duplicating your folder path. This usually happens when the files or cwd in docfx.json is set incorrectly. ✅ How to fix it Find the exact location of your .csproj. For example, let’s say it’s here: C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL\BradleyLeach_BooseApp\BradleyLeach_BooseApp.csproj Update your docfx.json metadata section to point to it relative to the docfx_project folder: Assuming your docfx_project folder is at: C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL\docfx_project Use: { "metadata": [ { "src": [ { "files": ["../BradleyLeach_BooseApp/BradleyLeach_BooseApp.csproj"] } ], "dest": "api" } ], "build": { "content": [ { "files": ["articles/**.md"] }, { "files": ["api/**.yml"] }, { "files": ["index.md"] } ], "dest": "_site" } } Run commands from docfx_project folder: docfx metadata docfx build docfx serve _site You should now see API documentation generated. 💡 Tip: Always make files relative to the docfx_project folder. Avoid absolute paths; if you do use them, make sure they’re correctly escaped in JSON (\\ in Windows paths). If you want, I can make a ready-to-use docfx.json specifically for your BradleyLeach_BooseApp folder so this works in one shot. Do you want me to do that? me: modift this with those changes { "$schema": "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docfx/main/schemas/docfx.schema.json", "metadata": [ { "src": [ { "src": "../C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL\BradleyLeach_BooseApp", "files": [ "/*.csproj" ] } ], "dest": "api" } ], "build": { "content": [ { "files": [ "/*.{md,yml}" ], "exclude": [ "_site/" ] } ], "resource": [ { "files": [ "images/" ] } ], "output": "_site", "template": [ "default", "modern" ], "globalMetadata": { "_appName": "BooseApp", "_appTitle": "BooseApp", "_enableSearch": true, "pdf": true } } } ChatGPT: Ah! That warning explains exactly what’s happening: ../ is currently not supported in glob pattern, please use ../ in src option instead. DocFX doesn’t allow ../ in the files glob, only in the "src" folder itself. In other words: files should be just the filename or pattern inside the folder. src should point to the folder containing the .csproj. Here’s how to fix your docfx.json: { "$schema": "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docfx/main/schemas/docfx.schema.json", "metadata": [ { "src": [ { "src": "../BradleyLeach_BooseApp", "files": [ "BradleyLeach_BooseApp.csproj" ] } ], "dest": "api" } ], "build": { "content": [ { "files": [ "**/*.{md,yml}" ], "exclude": [ "_site/**" ] } ], "resource": [ { "files": [ "images/**" ] } ], "output": "_site", "template": [ "default", "modern" ], "globalMetadata": { "_appName": "BooseApp", "_appTitle": "BooseApp", "_enableSearch": true, "pdf": true } } } ✅ Key change: "src": "../BradleyLeach_BooseApp", "files": [ "BradleyLeach_BooseApp.csproj" ] src points to the folder containing the .csproj. files is the name of the .csproj file inside that folder. No ../ in files. After saving, run inside docfx_project: docfx metadata docfx build docfx serve _site This should finally generate your API docs. If you want, I can also give you a version that automatically detects all .csproj files in subfolders, so you won’t have to manually change docfx.json if you add projects later. Do you want me to do that?

api/BradleyLeach_BooseApp.html.title: Namespace BradleyLeach_BooseApp | BooseApp
api/BradleyLeach_BooseApp.html.summary: Namespace BradleyLeach_BooseApp Classes AppArray Represents an array variable (int or real) in the program, supporting both declaration and array operations. Provides logic for array creation, parameter validation, and value access/modification. AppBoolean Represents a boolean variable or expression within the program. Provides logic for compiling and evaluating boolean values. AppBooseFacade Facade class for storing all BOOSE app funcionality together, keeps GUI form clean from any BOOSE dependent code. AppCanvas This class is responsible for drawing on the canvas. AppCircle Command class to draw circle centered at the current position with specified radius. AppCommandFactory Factory class to create BOOSE application specific commands. AppCompoundCommand Represents a compound control flow command (such as if, while, for, or switch) that can contain nested commands. Inherits from AppConditionalCommand and provides linking to the corresponding control command. AppConditionalCommand Base class for conditional control flow commands such as if, while, and for. Provides common properties and logic for managing block structure and condition evaluation. AppDrawTo Command class to draw a line from the current position to a specified position. AppElse Command class representing an 'else' block in the program. Handles control flow for the 'else' part of an if-else conditional structure. AppEnd Command class representing the end of a control flow block (if, while, for) in the program. Handles linking to the corresponding start command and manages control flow for loops. AppFill Command class for the shape fill toggle command. AppFor Command class representing a 'for' loop block in the program. Evaluates start, end, and step expressions, manages the loop variable, and controls program flow for iteration. AppICanvasAdapter Adapter class responsible for porting core BOOSE command class' / interfaces to the new app version. Allows for additional canvas functionality with the IAppCanvas interface. AppIf Command class representing an 'if' conditional block in the program. Evaluates a boolean condition and controls program flow based on the result. AppInt Command class responsible for dealing with Integer type varaibles. AppMoveTo Command class to move the current drawing position to a specified position. AppNoCommand Blank BOOSE command that does nothing. Used for maintaining correct line numbering in case of commands with invlaid syntax. AppParser Parser class to interpret BOOSE commands for the application. AppPeek Command class for reading a value from an array at a specified index (peek operation) and assigning it to a variable. Inherits from AppArray and implements the peek logic for both int and real arrays. AppPenColour Command class to change the current pen colour to specified RGB values. AppPoke Command class for writing a value into an array at a specified index (poke operation). Inherits from AppArray and implements the poke logic for both int and real arrays. AppReal Command class responsible for dealing with Floating point (Real) varaibles. AppRect Command class to draw a rectangle of specified width and height from the current position. AppStoredProgram Stored program responsible for storing commands and executing them, extends base StoredProgram class. AppWhile Command class representing a 'while' loop block in the program. Evaluates a boolean condition and controls program flow to repeat the block while the condition is true. AppWrite Command class for writing text or evaluated expressions to the canvas. Form1 Represents the main form of the application, providing the user interface for rendering a canvas, parsing and executing commands, and displaying runtime results or errors. Interfaces IAppCanvas Overridden BOOSE.ICanvas interface to allow for custom methods for additional commands to AppCanvas. Enums AppConditionalCommand.conditionalTypes Enumeration of supported conditional command types.
